The sixth poured out his bowl upon the great river Euphrates, and its water was dried up to prepare the way for the kings from the rising of the sun.
Then I saw three foul spirits like frogs coming out of the mouth of the dragon, out of the mouth of the beast, and out of the mouth of the false prophet.
For they are demonic spirits performing miraculous signs, who go out to the kings of the whole inhabited world to mobilize them for battle on the Great Day of God, the Sovereign over all.
“Look! I am coming like a thief. Blessed is the one who stays alert and keeps his clothes at hand, so that he does not walk around naked and let people see his shameful exposure.”
And the spirits gathered the kings to the place called in Hebrew *Har-Magedon*.
The seventh poured out his bowl into the air. A loud voice came out of the sanctuary from the throne, saying, “It is finished!”

There followed flashes of lightning, rumblings, and peals of thunder, and a massive earthquake occurred—such as has never happened since humanity appeared on the earth, so great and mighty was this earthquake.
The great city was split into three parts, and the cities of the nations fell. God called Great Babylon to mind, giving her the cup filled with the wine of his fierce, fuming fury.
Every island vanished, and mountains could no longer be found.

Huge hailstones, weighing nearly a hundred pounds each, fell from heaven onto the people. And the people blasphemed God because of the plague of hail, for the disaster it brought was exceedingly great.

chapters.notes:
**"Sanctuary" (v. 1, 17)**: The Greek *naos* refers specifically to the inner shrine or the holy precinct where God dwells, rather than the *hieron*, which encompasses the entire temple complex.

**"Libation bowls" (v. 1)**: The *phialē* was a shallow, saucer-like vessel used in the Greco-Roman world and the Jewish temple for pouring out drink offerings (libations). The imagery suggests that the wrath of God is being "offered" back as a ritual consequence.

**"Fuming fury" (v. 1, 19)**: The Greek *thumos* denotes a turbulent, boiling passion or "burning" anger, distinguished from *orgē* (settled wrath). When used together in v. 19 (*tou thumou tēs orgēs*), it suggests the outward breaking forth of a long-stored indignation.

**"Living creature" (v. 3)**: The Greek *psuchē zōēs* ("soul of life") is a Hebraism (from the Septuagint’s *nephesh chayah*) referring to any breathing, living being.

**"Sovereign over all" (v. 7, 14)**: *Pantokratōr* is the Greek rendering of the Hebrew *Yahweh Sabaoth* (Lord of Hosts). It implies not just "Almighty" power, but the active exercise of universal dominion and governance.

**"Sovereignty" (v. 9)**: *Exousia* is more than "power" (*dunamis*); it is the legal and moral right to exercise authority. The text emphasizes that God remains the rightful governor even over the plagues that afflict the rebellious.

**"Whole inhabited world" (v. 14)**: *Oikoumenē* refers to the civilized world known to the original audience, often used specifically for the Roman Empire, but here extended to the cosmic scope of the gathering against God.

**"Shameful exposure" (v. 15)**: The Greek *aschēmosunē* refers to nakedness in a social or cultic sense that brings disgrace. In the first-century context, being caught without one's outer garment was a source of profound public shame.

**"Har-Magedon" (v. 16)**: Retained as a transliteration of the Hebrew *Har Megiddo* (Mountain of Megiddo). Megiddo was a strategic site of many historical battles in Israel’s history, symbolizing a final place of decisive judgment.

**"It is finished" (v. 17)**: The verb *gegonen* (perfect tense of *ginomai*) literally means "It has happened" or "It has come to pass." It signals the completion of God’s decree and the arrival of the end-state of the current age.

**"Called to mind" (v. 19)**: The passive *emnēsthē* ("was remembered") is a "divine passive," implying that God has now stepped in to act upon the sins he had seemingly overlooked. In biblical idiom, when God "remembers," he acts.

**"Weighing nearly a hundred pounds" (v. 21)**: The Greek *talantiaia* means "the weight of a talent." While talent weights varied, the Attic talent was approximately 57 lbs, while others reached nearly 100 lbs. The translation chooses a modern equivalent to convey the terrifying, terminal nature of the hail.

verses.text: Then one of the seven angels who held the seven bowls came and spoke with me, saying, “Come, I will show you the sentence passed against the great prostitute who sits enthroned over many waters.
The kings of the earth have committed sexual infidelity with her, and those who inhabit the earth have become intoxicated with the wine of her prostitution.”
He then carried me away in a prophetic trance into a wilderness. There I saw a woman sitting on a scarlet beast that was covered with blasphemous names and had seven heads and ten horns.

The woman was clothed in purple and scarlet and was gilded with gold, precious stones, and pearls. In her hand she held a golden cup filled with abominations and the ritual impurities of her prostitution.
On her forehead was written a name with a hidden symbolic meaning: “Babylon the Great, the mother of prostitutes and of the abominations of the earth.”
I saw that the woman was drunk—not with wine, but with the blood of God’s holy people and the blood of those who bore witness to Jesus. When I saw her, I was struck with utter amazement.
But the angel said to me, “Why are you amazed? I will explain to you the hidden symbolic meaning of the woman and of the beast that carries her, the one with the seven heads and ten horns.

The beast that you saw was, and now is not, and is about to ascend from the Abyss and go to its final destruction. The inhabitants of the earth—those whose names have not been written in the book of life since the foundation of the world—will be astonished when they see the beast, because it was, and is not, and yet will be present.
This calls for a mind that possesses wisdom: The seven heads are seven mountains on which the woman sits. They are also seven kings.
Five have fallen, one is currently reigning, and the other has not yet come; and when he does come, he must remain for only a little while.
As for the beast that was and is not, it is an eighth king, yet it belongs to the seven, and it is heading for destruction.
The ten horns you saw are ten kings who have not yet received a kingdom, but they receive sovereign authority as kings for a single hour along with the beast.
These kings share a single purpose, and they hand over their power and authority to the beast.
They will make war against the Lamb, but the Lamb will conquer them because he is Lord of lords and King of kings—and those with him are the called, the chosen, and the faithful.”
Then he said to me, “The waters you saw, where the prostitute sits enthroned, are peoples and multitudes and nations and languages.
And the ten horns you saw and the beast—these will come to hate the prostitute. They will leave her desolated and naked; they will devour her flesh and consume her with fire.
For God has put it into their hearts to carry out his purpose by being of one mind and giving their royal sovereignty to the beast until the words of God are fulfilled.
And the woman you saw is the great city that holds sovereign power over the kings of the earth.”

chapters.notes:
**"Sentence passed" (v. 1)**: The Greek *krima* refers to the result of a judgment—the verdict or the execution of the sentence—rather than the abstract process of judging.

**"Prostitute / Prostitution" (vv. 1, 2, 5)**: The term *pornē* in prophetic literature (following the Septuagint's use of the Hebrew *zanah*) refers to more than literal sex work. It denotes a city or nation that is unfaithful to God through idolatry or a city that sells its influence and luxury to other nations for gain. "Sexual infidelity" (v. 2) captures this metaphor of political and religious betrayal.

**"Prophetic trance" (v. 3)**: The phrase *en pneumati* (literally "in spirit") describes the visionary state of the prophet, similar to being "in the Spirit" in Revelation 1:10. It implies a relocation of the consciousness by divine power.

**"Gilded" (v. 4)**: *Kechrysōmenē* means to be covered or plated with gold. It suggests an outward display of extreme, almost gaudy, wealth.

**"Abominations" (vv. 4, 5)**: *Bdelygmata* is a specific term in the Septuagint for idols and the detestable practices associated with pagan worship. It carries a heavy sense of ritual defilement.

**"Hidden symbolic meaning" (vv. 5, 7)**: The Greek *mystērion* does not mean a "mystery" in the modern sense of a puzzle to be solved, but a secret truth or a symbolic reality that can only be understood through divine revelation.

**"Those who bore witness" (v. 6)**: The Greek *martyrōn* refers to witnesses. While this is the root of the English "martyr," in the first century, the emphasis was on the act of testifying to the truth, even unto death.

**"The Abyss" (v. 8)**: *Abyssos* refers to the bottomless deep, understood in Jewish apocalyptic thought as the prison-house of demons and chaotic powers.

**"Will be present" (v. 8)**: The Greek *parestai* is a play on the word *parousia* (arrival/presence). The beast mimics the "coming" of Christ, appearing as a parody of the one "who was and is and is to come."

**"Mountains" (v. 9)**: For a first-century reader, "seven mountains" (*hepta orē*) was a ubiquitous shorthand for the city of Rome, famously known as the city on seven hills.

**"Desolated" (v. 16)**: *Ērēmōmenēn* means to be turned into a wilderness or a desert. It implies the total stripping of resources and population.

**"Sovereign power" (v. 18)**: *Basileia* is usually translated as "kingdom," but in this context, it refers to the exercise of imperial dominion or the right to rule over others.

verses.text: After these things, I saw another angel coming down from heaven. He possessed great authority, and the earth was flooded with light from his radiance.

He cried out with a mighty voice, saying: “Fallen! Fallen is Babylon the Great! She has become a haunt for demons, a place of confinement for every unclean spirit, a cage for every unclean bird, and a haunt for every unclean and loathsome beast.

For all the nations have collapsed from the wine of the intoxicating passion of her sexual immorality; the kings of the earth committed immoral acts with her, and the merchants of the earth grew rich from the power of her unrestrained luxury.”
Then I heard another voice from heaven saying: “Come out of her, my people, so that you do not participate in her sins and so that you do not receive a share of her plagues.
For her sins have been piled as high as heaven, and God has called to mind her crimes.
Pay her back exactly as she herself paid out; pay her back double for what she has done. In the cup she mixed, mix a double portion for her.

To the same extent that she glorified herself and lived in arrogant luxury, give her torment and mourning. For in her heart she says, ‘I sit enthroned as a queen; I am no widow, and I will never see mourning.’
For this reason, her plagues will come in a single day—death and mourning and famine—and she will be burned up with fire. For strong is the Lord God who has judged her.”
The kings of the earth, who committed immoral acts and lived in luxury with her, will weep and wail over her when they see the smoke of her burning.
They will stand at a distance because of their fear of her torment, saying: “Woe! Woe, O great city! Babylon, the mighty city! In a single hour your judgment has come.”
And the merchants of the earth weep and mourn over her, because no one buys their cargo anymore—

cargo of gold, silver, precious stones, and pearls; fine linen, purple cloth, silk, and scarlet cloth; every kind of citron wood and every object made of ivory; every object made of the costliest wood, bronze, iron, and marble;
cinnamon, exotic spice, incense, fragrant ointment, frankincense, wine, olive oil, fine flour, and wheat; cattle, sheep, horses, and carriages; and human bodies—that is, the lives of people.
The fruit your soul craved has left you, and all your delicacies and splendors have perished from you; people will never find them again.
The merchants of these things, who grew rich from her, will stand at a distance because of their fear of her torment, weeping and mourning,
saying: “Woe! Woe, O great city, clothed in fine linen, purple, and scarlet, and gilded with gold, precious stones, and pearls!
In a single hour such vast wealth has been laid waste.” Every shipmaster, every seafarer, sailors, and all who work the sea stood at a distance
and cried out as they saw the smoke of her burning, saying: “What city was ever like this great city?”

They threw dust on their heads and cried out, weeping and mourning, saying: “Woe! Woe, O great city, in which all who had ships on the sea grew rich from her abundance! In a single hour she has been laid waste.”
Rejoice over her, O heaven, and you holy ones, apostles, and prophets! For God has executed the judgment against her that she intended for you.

Then a single mighty angel picked up a stone like a huge millstone and hurled it into the sea, saying: “With this kind of violence, Babylon the great city will be thrown down, and she will never be found again.

The sound of harpists, musicians, flute players, and trumpeters will never be heard in you again; no craftsman of any trade will ever be found in you again; the sound of a millstone will never be heard in you again;

the light of a lamp will never shine in you again; and the voice of the bridegroom and bride will never be heard in you again. For your merchants were the tycoons of the earth, and by your sorcery all the nations were led astray.
And in her was found the blood of prophets and of holy ones, and of all those who have been slaughtered on the earth.”

chapters.notes:
**"Haunt / Place of confinement" (v. 2)**: The Greek *phylakē* is often translated as "prison," but in this context of a ruined city, it refers to a place where these unclean things are restricted or where they congregate. "Haunt" and "cage" (for the birds) capture the imagery of a desolate ruin.

**"Intoxicating passion" (v. 3)**: The Greek *thymos* can mean "wrath" or "passionate desire." Given the pairing with "wine" and "immorality," it refers to the heated, driving passion of her seduction, which leads to God's eventual "wrath."

**"Unrestrained luxury" (v. 3, 7)**: The term *strēnos* refers to a defiant, insolent kind of luxury—the kind of wealth that leads to arrogance and a rejection of God. 

**"Piled as high as heaven" (v. 5)**: The verb *ekollēthēsan* literally means "glued" or "welded." The image is of sins being stuck together in a massive heap that eventually reaches the heavens.

**"Human bodies—that is, the lives of people" (v. 13)**: The Greek text lists *sōmatōn* (bodies) and *psychas anthrōpōn* (souls/lives of humans). In the first century, *sōmata* was a standard technical term for slaves. The author adds "lives of people" to emphasize the human cost of Babylon’s commerce; she doesn't just trade goods, but the very essence of human beings.

**"Fruit your soul craved" (v. 14)**: Literally, "the autumn fruit (*opōra*) of the desire of your soul." 

**"Executed the judgment against her that she intended for you" (v. 20)**: The Greek *ekrinen ho theos to krima hymōn ex autēs* is idiomatic. It means God has judged her with the very judgment she had imposed on the believers, or perhaps "vindicated your cause" against her.

**"Tycoons" (v. 23)**: The Greek *megistanes* refers to the great men, the magnates, or the high-ranking officials. In a commercial context, "tycoons" or "merchant princes" captures the status these traders held due to Babylon's influence.

**"Sorcery" (v. 23)**: The Greek *pharmakeia* refers to the use of drugs, potions, or spells. It suggests that Babylon’s influence wasn't just economic, but a kind of deceptive enchantment or "drugging" of the nations to bring them under her sway.

verses.text: After these things, I heard what sounded like the roar of a vast multitude in heaven, shouting: “Hallelujah! Salvation and glory and power belong to our God,

because his judgments are true and just. He has judged the great prostitute who corrupted the earth with her sexual immorality, and he has exacted vindication for the blood of his servants at her hand.”
And a second time they shouted: “Hallelujah! The smoke from her goes up forever and ever.”
Then the twenty-four elders and the four living beings fell down and worshiped God, who is seated on the throne, saying: “Amen! Hallelujah!”
And a voice came from the throne, saying: “Give praise to our God, all you his servants, you who fear him, both the small and the great.”

Then I heard what sounded like the roar of a vast multitude, like the roar of many rushing waters, and like the roar of mighty peals of thunder, shouting: “Hallelujah! For the Lord our God, the All-Ruler, has begun his reign.
Let us rejoice and exult and give him the glory, because the wedding day of the Lamb has come, and his bride has made herself ready.
It was granted to her to clothe herself in fine linen, bright and pure”—for the fine linen represents the righteous deeds of the holy ones.
And the angel said to me, “Write this: Blessed are those who have been invited to the wedding banquet of the Lamb.” And he said to me, “These are the true words of God.”

Then I fell at his feet to worship him, but he said to me, “Do not do that! I am a fellow servant with you and with your brothers and sisters who hold to the testimony of Jesus. Worship God! For the testimony of Jesus is the spirit of prophecy.”
Then I saw heaven standing open, and behold, a white horse! The one sitting on it is called Faithful and True, and in righteousness he judges and makes war.
His eyes are like a flame of fire, and on his head are many royal diadems. He has a name written on him that no one knows except himself.
He is clothed in a robe dipped in blood, and the name by which he is called is the Logos of God.
The armies of heaven, wearing fine linen, white and pure, were following him on white horses.
From his mouth comes a sharp broadsword with which to strike down the nations, and he will shepherd them with an iron staff. He treads the winepress of the furious wrath of God the All-Ruler.
And he has a name written on his robe and on his thigh: King of kings and Lord of lords.
Then I saw an angel standing in the sun, and he cried out with a great voice to all the birds flying in mid-heaven: “Come, gather together for the great banquet of God,
so that you may eat the flesh of kings, the flesh of commanders, the flesh of the mighty, the flesh of horses and their riders, and the flesh of all people—both free and slave, both small and great.”
And I saw the beast and the kings of the earth and their armies gathered to make war against the one sitting on the horse and against his army.

And the beast was captured, and with it the false prophet who performed the signs in its presence, by which he deceived those who had received the mark of the beast and those who worshiped its image. These two were thrown alive into the lake of fire that burns with sulfur.
And the rest were killed by the broadsword of the one sitting on the horse—the sword that comes out of his mouth—and all the birds gorged themselves on their flesh.

chapters.notes:
**"Hallelujah" (v. 1, 3, 4, 6)**: This is a transliteration of the Hebrew *halelu-yah* ("Praise Yahweh"). Its presence in the Greek text reflects the liturgical language of the early Jewish-Christian community, preserved as a sacred shout of victory.

**"Exacted vindication... at her hand" (v. 2)**: The Greek *exedikēsen... ek cheiros autēs* follows a Semitic idiom (Aramaic/Hebrew). It implies not just getting revenge, but holding her legally responsible for the "debt" of blood she spilled.

**"All-Ruler" (v. 6, 15)**: The Greek *pantokratōr* is often translated "Almighty," but it specifically means "the one who has his hand on everything" or "the Sovereign over all." In the context of the Roman Empire, this was a direct counter-claim to the "totalitarian" claims of the Caesars.

**"Has begun his reign" (v. 6)**: The aorist verb *ebasileusen* is ingressive here, marking the beginning of a new state of affairs—God’s active, manifest sovereignty over the earth.

**"Righteous deeds" (v. 8)**: The Greek *dikaiōmata* is plural. While *dikaiosynē* often refers to a state of righteousness or justification, *dikaiōmata* refers to the concrete, outward acts or requirements of justice performed by the "holy ones" (saints).

**"Logos" (v. 13)**: Retained as a loanword per the guidelines. To a first-century reader, this identified the rider with the divine creative reason of the prologue of the Fourth Gospel and the "Word of God" that active in Old Testament judgment and creation.

**"Royal diadems" (v. 12)**: The Greek *diadēmata* refers to royal crowns, the symbols of kingship, as opposed to *stephanoi*, which were the laurel wreaths given to victorious athletes or generals.

**"Broadsword" (v. 15, 21)**: The Greek *rhomphaia* refers to a large, heavy sword (often Thracian in origin), distinct from the smaller *machaira* (dagger or short sword). It emphasizes the overwhelming and devastating nature of the judgment.

**"Shepherd them with an iron staff" (v. 15)**: This alludes to Psalm 2:9. The Greek *poimanei* ("he will shepherd") is used ironically here; instead of the gentle care of a shepherd, the "rod" or "staff" is made of iron, signifying an unbreakable rule.

**"Mid-heaven" (v. 17)**: The Greek *mesouranēmati* refers to the highest point of the sky, the zenith, where the sun is at noon and anything appearing there would be visible to all.

verses.text: And I saw a messenger descending from the heavens, holding the key to the Abyss and a great chain in his hand.
He seized the dragon—that ancient serpent, who is the Slanderer and the Adversary—and bound him for a thousand years.

He threw him into the Abyss, then shut and sealed it over him, so that he could no longer lead the nations astray until the thousand years were completed. After these things, he must be released for a short time.

Then I saw thrones, and those who sat on them were entrusted with the authority to judge. I also saw the souls of those who had been executed by the axe because of their testimony about Jesus and because of the word of God. These are the ones who had not worshiped the beast or its image and had not received its brand on their foreheads or their hands. They came to life and reigned with the Christ for a thousand years.
(The rest of the dead did not come to life until the thousand years were completed.) This is the first resurrection.

Favored and holy is the one who shares in the first resurrection! Over these, the second death has no authority, but they will be priests of God and of the Christ, and they will reign with him for the thousand years.
When the thousand years are completed, the Adversary will be released from his prison
and will go out to lead astray the nations at the four corners of the earth—Gog and Magog—to mobilize them for battle. Their number is like the sand of the sea.
They marched up across the broad plain of the earth and encircled the encampment of the holy ones and the beloved city. But fire came down from heaven and devoured them.

And the Slanderer, who had been leading them astray, was thrown into the lake of fire and sulfur where the beast and the false prophet were, and they will be tormented day and night into the ages of ages.
Then I saw a great white throne and the one seated upon it. From his presence the earth and the heavens fled away, and no place was found for them.

And I saw the dead, the great and the small, standing before the throne, and scrolls were opened. Then another scroll was opened, which is the Scroll of Life. The dead were judged by what was written in the scrolls, according to their deeds.
The sea gave up the dead that were in it, and Death and Hades gave up the dead that were in them, and each person was judged according to their deeds.
Then Death and Hades were thrown into the lake of fire. This—the lake of fire—is the second death.
And if anyone’s name was not found written in the Scroll of Life, they were thrown into the lake of fire.

chapters.notes:
**"The Abyss" (v. 1, 3)**: The Greek *abyssos* evokes the primordial deep of Genesis 1, which in the Second Temple Jewish worldview (e.g., 1 Enoch) became the designated prison for fallen celestial beings. Translating it as "bottomless pit" captures the depth but loses the cosmological connection to the "deep."

**"Slanderer and the Adversary" (v. 2)**: The Greek *Diabolos* means "the Slanderer" or "the Accuser," while *Satanas* is a transliteration of the Hebrew *Satan*, meaning "the Adversary." Using these descriptive titles restores the legal and functional roles these names played for the original audience.

**"Executed by the axe" (v. 4)**: The Greek *pepeleksimenōn* is highly specific, referring to the *pelekys* or the Roman *fasces* (the axe-and-rod symbol of magistrate authority). It denotes a formal state execution, specifically beheading, which was the Roman punishment for citizens.

**"The Christ" (v. 4, 6)**: The Greek includes the definite article (*tou christou*). In the first century, *Christos* was not a last name but a title—"the Anointed One"—referring to the Messianic King of Israel.

**"The second death" (v. 6, 14)**: This is a technical term found in the Aramaic Targums (Jewish paraphrases of the Hebrew Bible) of the period. It refers specifically to the final, permanent death of the soul in the age to come, as distinct from the first, physical death.

**"Hades" (v. 13-14)**: In the 1st-century context, Hades is the Greek equivalent of the Hebrew *Sheol*—the temporary, intermediate realm of the dead, both righteous and unrighteous. It is distinct from the "lake of fire" (the final destination), which is why Hades itself is eventually cast into the lake of fire.

**"Scroll" (v. 12, 15)**: The Greek *biblion* refers to a papyrus or parchment scroll, the standard medium for legal records and literature in the first century. "Book" can imply a modern codex, whereas "scroll" better captures the visual of a record being unrolled for judgment.

verses.text: Then I saw a fresh heaven and a fresh earth; for the first heaven and the first earth had passed away, and the sea—the realm of chaos—was no more.
And I saw the holy city, New Jerusalem, descending out of heaven from God, prepared like a bride adorned for her husband.

And I heard a loud voice from the throne saying, “Look! God’s dwelling-tent is now among human beings. He will pitch his tent among them, and they will be his peoples. God himself will be with them as their God.
He will blot out every tear from their eyes. Death will be no more; neither will there be mourning, nor wailing, nor pain anymore. The former things have passed away.”
Then the one seated on the throne said, “Look! I am making all things new.” And he said, “Write this down, because these words are trustworthy and true.”
And he said to me, “It is finished! I am the Alpha and the Omega, the Beginning and the End. To the one who thirsts, I will give water from the spring of the water of life as a gift.
The one who emerges victorious will inherit these things; I will be God to him, and he will be a son to me.

But as for the cowardly, the faithless, the detestable, the murderers, the sexually immoral, the practitioners of magic potions, the idol-worshipers, and all who are liars—their portion is in the lake that burns with fire and sulfur, which is the second death.”
Then one of the seven angels who held the seven bowls filled with the seven final plagues came and spoke with me, saying, “Come, I will show you the bride, the wife of the Lamb.”
And he carried me away in a Spirit-led trance to a great and high mountain, and he showed me the holy city Jerusalem, descending out of heaven from God.
It possessed the radiance of God. Its brilliance was like a most precious stone, like a crystal-clear jasper.
It had a great, high wall with twelve gates, and twelve angels were at the gates. Names were inscribed on them, which are the names of the twelve tribes of the sons of Israel.
There were three gates on the east, three gates on the north, three gates on the south, and three gates on the west.
The wall of the city had twelve foundation stones, and on them were the twelve names of the twelve apostles of the Lamb.
The one speaking with me had a gold measuring rod to measure the city, its gates, and its wall.
The city is laid out as a square; its length is as great as its width. He measured the city with the rod at twelve thousand stadia; its length, width, and height are equal.
He also measured its wall: one hundred forty-four cubits by a human measurement, which the angel was using.
The structure of its wall was jasper, and the city was pure gold, clear as transparent glass.
The foundation stones of the city wall were adorned with every kind of precious stone: the first foundation stone was jasper, the second sapphire, the third chalcedony, the fourth emerald,
the fifth sardonyx, the sixth carnelian, the seventh chrysolite, the eighth beryll, the ninth topaz, the tenth chrysoprase, the eleventh hyacinth, and the twelfth amethyst.
The twelve gates were twelve pearls; each individual gate was made of a single pearl. And the broad plaza of the city was pure gold, like transparent glass.
I saw no sanctuary in the city, for the Lord God, the Ruler of All, is its sanctuary—as is the Lamb.
The city has no need of the sun or the moon to shine on it, for the radiance of God illuminated it, and its lamp is the Lamb.
The nations will walk by means of its light, and the kings of the earth will bring their glory into it.
Its gates will never be closed by day—and there will be no night there.
They will bring the glory and the honor of the nations into it.
But nothing profane, nor anyone who practices detestable things or falsehood, will ever enter it—only those who have been written in the Lamb’s Book of Life.

chapters.notes:
**"Fresh" (v. 1, 2, 5)**: The Greek *kainos* denotes something new in quality or nature, rather than simply new in time (*neos*). It suggests a renewal or a superior replacement of the old, rather than just a chronological successor.

**"The sea—the realm of chaos" (v. 1)**: For the original audience, the sea (*thalassa*) was often a symbol of the primeval chaos, the abyss, and the source of the beastly powers that oppose God (cf. Daniel 7, Revelation 13). Its absence signifies the total removal of chaos and the threat of evil.

**"Dwelling-tent" / "Pitch his tent" (v. 3)**: The Greek *skēnē* (noun) and *skēnōsei* (verb) are direct allusions to the Tabernacle of the Hebrew Scriptures. In a Jewish context, this also evokes the *Shekhinah*—the localized, indwelling presence of God.

**"Peoples" (v. 3)**: The SBLGNT uses the plural *laoi* (peoples). While many traditional translations use the singular "people," the plural reflects the inclusive nature of the New Jerusalem, where all nations and ethnic groups become God’s own.

**"Blot out" (v. 4)**: *Exaleipsō* means to wipe away or erase, often used of washing off ink from papyrus. It suggests the total removal of the record of sorrow.

**"Practitioners of magic potions" (v. 8)**: *Pharmakois* refers to those who deal in *pharmakeia*. In the first century, this involved the use of drugs for spells, poisoning, or ritual sorcery. "Sorcerers" is the traditional rendering, but "practitioners of magic potions" captures the medicinal/chemical element of the Greek term.

**"Spirit-led trance" (v. 10)**: *En pneumati* (literally "in spirit") refers to the prophetic state of being, where the author is transported by the Holy Spirit into a visionary experience.

**"Radiance" / "Luminary" (v. 11, 23)**: *Phōstēr* (v. 11) refers to a light-bearing body or the radiance it emits. It is the same word used in the Septuagint for the sun and moon in Genesis 1.

**"Twelve thousand stadia" (v. 16)**: A *stadion* was approximately 600 feet. Twelve thousand stadia is roughly 1,400 miles. The key significance is the number 12 (the number of God's people) and the fact that the city is a perfect cube, the same shape as the Holy of Holies in the Temple.

**"Sanctuary" (v. 22)**: *Naos* refers specifically to the inner temple, the dwelling place of the deity, rather than the *hieron* (the entire temple complex). The city has no need for a restricted sacred space because the entire city has become the Holy of Holies.

**"Profane" (v. 27)**: *Koinon* literally means "common." In a cultic or religious sense, it means something that is ritually "unclean" or has not been set apart for God.

verses.text: Then he showed me a river of the water of life, sparkling like crystal, flowing from the throne of God and of the Lamb

through the middle of the city’s main street. On either side of the river stood the tree of life, producing twelve kinds of fruit, yielding its fruit every month; and the leaves of the tree were for the healing of the nations.
And every accursed thing will exist no longer. The throne of God and of the Lamb will be in the city, and his bondservants will offer him cultic worship.
They will see his face, and his name will be on their foreheads.
Night will exist no more; they have no need for the light of a lamp or the light of the sun, because the Lord God will shine upon them, and they will reign forever and ever.
Then he said to me, “These words are faithful and true. The Lord, the God of the spirits of the prophets, has sent his messenger to show his bondservants what must take place without delay.”
“And look! I am coming quickly. Blessed is the one who keeps the words of the prophecy of this book.”
I, John, am the one who heard and saw these things. And when I heard and saw them, I fell down to worship at the feet of the messenger who showed them to me.
But he said to me, “Don’t do that! I am a fellow servant with you, with your brothers the prophets, and with those who keep the words of this book. Worship God!”
Then he told me, “Do not seal up the words of the prophecy of this book, for the time is near.
Let the one who does wrong continue to do wrong; let the filthy one continue to be filthy; let the righteous one continue to practice righteousness; and let the holy one continue to be kept holy.”
“Look! I am coming quickly, and my reward is with me, to pay back each person according to what they have done.
I am the Alpha and the Omega, the First and the Last, the Beginning and the End.
Blessed are those who wash their robes, so that they may have the right to the tree of life and may enter the city by its gates.
Outside are the dogs, the sorcerers, the sexually immoral, the murderers, the idolaters, and everyone who loves and practices falsehood.”
“I, Jesus, have sent my messenger to testify these things to you for the sake of the churches. I am the Root and the descendant of David, the bright morning star.”
Both the Spirit and the Bride say, “Come!” And let the one who hears say, “Come!” And let the one who is thirsty come; let the one who desires it take the water of life as a free gift.
I testify to everyone who hears the words of the prophecy of this book: if anyone adds to them, God will add to him the plagues described in this book;
and if anyone takes away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God will take away his share of the tree of life and of the holy city, which are described in this book.
The one who testifies to these things says, “Yes, I am coming quickly.” Amen. Come, Lord Jesus!
The grace of the Lord Jesus be with all.

chapters.notes:
**"Main street" (v. 2)**: The Greek *plateia* refers to a broad, open street or public square. In the context of the New Jerusalem, it suggests the primary thoroughfare where the community gathers.

**"Tree of life" (v. 2)**: The Greek *xylon* literally means "wood" or "timber," but in the Septuagint and the New Testament, it is frequently used for a living tree (echoing Genesis 2:9). The description of the tree being on "either side" of the river suggests either a grove of trees or a singular life-giving reality that spans the water.

**"Accursed thing" (v. 3)**: The Greek *katathema* refers to something devoted to destruction or a curse. It evokes the Hebrew *herem* (the "ban" or things set apart for divine judgment). Its removal signals the total reversal of the Fall and the end of Zechariah 14:11's "curse."

**"Cultic worship" (v. 3)**: The verb *latreuō* refers specifically to the service and worship offered to a deity, often in a priestly or ritual context. It is more specific than general service (*douleuō*).

**"Messenger" (v. 6, 8, 16)**: While traditionally translated as "angel," the Greek *angelos* simply means "messenger." Given the book's emphasis on the communication of a divine revelation, "messenger" preserves the functional role of the figure.

**"Without delay" (v. 6)**: The phrase *en tachei* is often translated "soon," but in Greek, it carries a sense of speed or "with haste." It suggests that once the events begin, they will proceed rapidly to their conclusion.

**"Let the filthy one continue..." (v. 11)**: This difficult verse uses imperatives (*rhypareuthētō*, etc.). To a first-century reader, this wasn't an encouragement to sin, but a rhetorical device emphasizing the fixity of character at the moment of the end. The window for change is closing; what one has become is what one will be.

**"Dogs" (v. 15)**: In the first-century Mediterranean world, "dogs" (*kynes*) were not pets but scavengers. In Jewish idiom, the term was a pejorative for the ritually impure, the lawless, or those outside the covenant (cf. Philippians 3:2).

**"Sorcerers" (v. 15)**: The Greek *pharmakoi* refers to those who use drugs, potions, or spells. It encompasses the occult and the manipulation of the divine through "medicine" or magic.

**"Washing their robes" (v. 14)**: The SBLGNT, following the earliest manuscripts (Codex Sinaiticus and Alexandrinus), reads "wash their robes" (*plynontes tas stolas autōn*) rather than "keep the commandments" (*poiountes tas entolas autou*), which is found in later manuscripts and the Textus Receptus.
